label: Line count
description:
The skirt is a line drawn around the object at the first layer. This helps to prime your extruder, and to see if the object fits on your platform.
Setting this to 0 will disable the skirt. Multiple skirt lines can help priming your extruder better for small objects.

label: Start distance (mm)
description:
The distance between the skirt and the first layer.
This is the minimal distance, multiple skirt lines will be put outwards from this distance.

label: Minimal length (mm)
description:
The minimal length of the skirt, if this minimal length is not reached it will add more skirt lines to reach this minimal lenght.
Note: If the line count is set to 0 this is ignored.

label: Fan full on at height (mm)
description: The height at which the fan is turned on completely. For the layers below this the fan speed is scaled linearly with the fan off at layer 0.

label: Fan speed min (%)
description: When the fan is turned on, it is enabled at this speed setting. If cool slows down the layer, the fan is adjusted between the min and max speed. Minimal fan speed is used if the layer is not slowed down due to cooling.

label: Fan speed max (%)
description: When the fan is turned on, it is enabled at this speed setting. If cool slows down the layer, the fan is adjusted between the min and max speed. Maximal fan speed is used if the layer is slowed down due to cooling by more than 200%.

label: Minimum speed (mm/s)
description: The minimal layer time can cause the print to slow down so much it starts to ooze. The minimal feedrate protects against this. Even if a print gets slowed down it will never be slower than this minimal speed.

label: Cool head lift
description: Lift the head if the minimal speed is hit because of cool slowdown, and wait the extra time so the minimal layer time is always hit.

label: Solid infill top
description: Create a solid top surface, if set to false the top is filled with the fill percentage. Useful for cups/vases.

label: Solid infill bottom
description: Create a solid bottom surface, if set to false the bottom is filled with the fill percentage. Useful for buildings.

label: Infill overlap (%)
description: Amount of overlap between the infill and the walls. There is a slight overlap with the walls and the infill so the walls connect firmly to the infill.

label: Infill prints after perimeters
description: Print infill after perimeter lines. This can reduce infill from showing through the surface. If not checked, infill will print before perimeter lines.

label: Spiralize the outer contour
description:
Spiralize is smoothing out the Z move of the outer edge. This will create a steady Z increase over the whole print. This feature turns a solid object into a single walled print with a solid bottom.
This feature used to be called Joris in older versions.

label: Only follow mesh surface
description: Only follow the mesh surfaces of the 3D model, do not do anything else. No infill, no top/bottom, nothing.

label: Brim line amount
description: The amount of lines used for a brim, more lines means a larger brim which sticks better, but this also makes your effective print area smaller.

label: Extra margin (mm)
description: If the raft is enabled, this is the extra raft area around the object which is also rafted. Increasing this margin will create a stronger raft while using more material and leaving less area for your print.

label: Line spacing (mm)
description: When you are using the raft this is the distance between the centerlines of the raft line.

label: Base thickness (mm)
description: When you are using the raft this is the thickness of the base layer which is put down.

label: Base line width (mm)
description: When you are using the raft this is the width of the base layer lines which are put down.

label: Interface thickness (mm)
description: When you are using the raft this is the thickness of the interface layer which is put down.

label: Interface line width (mm)
description: When you are using the raft this is the width of the interface layer lines which are put down.

label: Airgap
description: Gap between the last layer of the raft the whole print.

label: First Layer Airgap
description: Gap between the last layer of the raft and the first printing layer. A small gap of 0.2mm works wonders on PLA and makes the raft easy to remove. This value is added on top of the 'Airgap' setting.

label: Surface Layers
description: Amount of surface layers put on top of the raft, these are fully filled layers on which the model is printed.

label: Surface layer thickness (mm)
description: Thickness of each surface layer.

label: Surface layer line width (mm)
description: Width of the lines for each surface layer.

label: Combine everything (Type-A)
description: This expert option adds all parts of the model together. The result is usually that internal cavities disappear. Depending on the model this can be intended or not. Enabling this option is at your own risk. Type-A is dependent on the model normals and tries to keep some internal holes intact. Type-B ignores all internal holes and only keeps the outside shape per layer.

label: Combine everything (Type-B)
description: This expert option adds all parts of the model together. The result is usually that internal cavities disappear. Depending on the model this can be intended or not. Enabling this option is at your own risk. Type-A is dependent on the model normals and tries to keep some internal holes intact. Type-B ignores all internal holes and only keeps the outside shape per layer.

label: Keep open faces
description:
This expert option keeps all the open bits of the model intact. Normally Cura tries to stitch up small holes and remove everything with big holes, but this option keeps bits that are not properly part of anything and just goes with whatever is left. This option is usually not what you want, but it might enable you to slice models otherwise failing to produce proper paths.
As with all "Fix horrible" options, results may vary and use at your own risk.

label: Extensive stitching
description:
Extensive stitching tries to fix up open holes in the model by closing the hole with touching polygons. This algorthm is quite expensive and could introduce a lot of processing time.
As with all "Fix horrible" options, results may vary and use at your own risk.

label: Ooze shield
description:
The ooze shield is a 1 line thick shell around the object which stands a few mm from the object.
This shield catches any oozing from the unused nozzle in dual-extrusion.
